comments.commentBody:
"" But one thing I do know is if everyone started opening their own doors and taking out their own trash, as some on here have suggested (as if doormen are a decedent luxury), these to-be strike""

Hey dude, you dont really live in a doorman building, do you?

For your information = residents DONT HAVE A CHOICE. Doormen are a union tool forced upon the building owners/managers. They are a necessary evil to some degree. They are not always in existence at the demand of the residents. In some cases they are, to be sure. But dont blame the tenents for the existence of doormen. They are part and parcel of the mob mentality that bleeds the productive classes for whatever they can.

The writer of this article and those posting are overlooking the fact that there are buildings in New York that have elevator operators where people who are not wealthy live.  Many years ago, I scraped up enough money to purchase my apartment when the Upper West Side building in which I was renting went co-op.  It had old-fashioned elevators that had to be run by operators.  The elevator operators added an extra layer of security for the young struggling professionals, young families and elderly people who lived in my building.  When the union struck, we had to keep the elevators running so that the elderly man who lived on 14 and suffered an appendicitus attack could be taken down to the ambulance, and a pregnant woman could get to her medical checkup, the kids could  get to school and the rest of us could get to work.  I recall no one who had a cleaning person.  Just a bunch of middle class working stiffs, unemployed folks, students holding down menial jobs while finishing college and retirees living on fixed incomes.  New Yorkers comprise all income levels and live in all sorts of housing.  Remember that when you are tempted to generalize and stereotype.

For all of you commenting how high the doormen's salaries are..you've never lived in New York City. NYC is terribly expensive. Those doormen salaries do not go very far. And, remember, those people whose bags they carry all day long, many get multi-million dollar bonuses, and some have daddy-endowed trust-funds...so, they can afford to share a little more. Just sending a kid to a private school in NYC is $30,000, that's half of a doorman's wage AND benefits.

I live in a 24-hour doorman building in Brooklyn with my wife and our son.  We are not wealthy. Not everyone who lives in a doorman building are wealthy or sobs or elitists, although I'm sure many are. The staff in our building provide us with an invaluable service and I totally sympathize with them. I know them all by name and they are part of what we like about our building.  I hope they negotiate a satisfactory contract because they deserve it.  A big part of our personal budget is determined by our building maintenance but I don't begrudge the staff for the part that goes to pay their salaries.
well... we don't have many doormen here. the whole thing seems kind of strange, to me. sort the mail? greet the kids. these things don't really seem necessary. but they take out your trash? really?

I personally find doorman buildings creepy - the amount of knowledge the doormen have about the residents of their buildings is unsettling.  but for those who are afflicted, a few tips from a single woman lumping it in a prewar walkup: get signature confirmation on your packages so they won't be left in the lobby, take out your own trash, and relish your (temporary) privacy.

Lots of misunderstanding and resentment in these comments.

I live in a doorman building and I'm not pampered nor do I have a huge bonus. Lots of buildings have doormen, that's life in the city. They don't open the door for me, but they do accept / sign for packages and let me know if I have a visitor or delivery.

Pretty simple concept actually.
Commenter 7: "pampered poodles" – I am using this one from no on!!! That it exactly what some Upper East Siders remind me of.

I am completely appalled by the statements these people in the article have made. I just moved to NY in January due to the long commute from Philadelphia to college in NY, and although I may be a student, I am no stranger to living in wealthier communities. I grew up in a fairly wealthy area outside of Philadelphia, and I was for lack of better words "spoiled". Moving to NY was difficult for me because I didn't have a lot of money and I had to make large adjustments (i.e.- moving out of the suburbs, and carrying out many tasks that were done for me at home with my parents). I have always valued hard work, and I have worked for everything that I have now, but regardless of how much these people work and earn their "penthouse" apartments, this is the definition of pathetic. I am 21 years old, I live in Harlem, I'm slowly becoming accustomed to the loud atmosphere at night, but I live on my own, and I do everything for myself. It makes me angry that people would actually complain about having to take out their own trash, do you pay someone to dress you in the morning also? I understand that elderly citizens and people with disabilities may really rely on these services, but if you are living in a building where you can afford to have a doorman, I'm sure you can afford to find a caretaker or "helper" during the strike. I wonder what these people would do if they had to switch places with some of us that don't have the luxury of an elevator, or someone to take out their trash, or someone to clean their hallways. I hope these people realize how ridiculous they sound. MOST of the population has to do these things for themselves every day. I am grateful just to be able to live here, and have an apartment to live in and have a 20 minute subway ride to school instead of a 2 hour commute. This is the melting pot. This city is full of diversity, but this is not the kind of diversity that is good for a community. Learn to do things for yourself, and try to sound a little less stuck up and a little more capable. I think these are the people that never got the "I walked five miles, uphill, barefoot, in the snow to school when I was your age" speech. If I were a doorman, I'd probably go on strike for the sole fact that I would get a couple of days off from watching these people moan and groan about how hard it is to actually do something for yourself. You don't have my sympathy, and I think you will find you are in the minority on this issue.

The article doesn't even get to the doormen's demands until the last paragraphs.  The thrust is what these helpless rich morons will do without someone to sign their FedEx's but the doormen whose very lives depend on this strike are given short shrift.  New York Times, why must you prove correct Chomsky's opinion about you in every single article?

Could someone please explain how doormen's benefits are almost equal to their salaries?  An enumeration of these benefits would be useful.  Without the requested information, it's hard for an outlander to see how anyone can begrudge folks who work hard for rich people a living wage, which $40,000 doesn't equal in NY.

Once upon a time I lived in a 3rd floor walk up at 338 E. 49th St.  I had plenty of exposure to doormen when I visited my affluent friends on Park Avenue.  Now I live in Black River Falls, WI, a town of 3618 souls.  Every Saturday and Sunday I have coffee with friends at the Cheese Hut, operated by the Hixton-Fairchild Farm Co-op, in Hixton, WI. (pop.435)  The coffee is the equal of Starbucks.  We talk about the fact that it costs about $16.00/hundredweight to produce milk that only sells for $14.00/hundredweight.  Sometimes we talk about when we will start planting and what the futures market is telling us.  Often we just shoot the breeze.  This coming Saturday I'll bring up the NYC doorman situation.  I'll share our ideas about a solution.  Stay tuned.
I am willing to work as a doorman for 40k. Can I replace one of the 70k doormen? I'll be graduating this summer with an engineering degree.

I lived in a doorman building for a year and while I was personally friendly with them (and still say hi when I go back), they were by no means essential, or even particularly useful.

They were, however, very expensive, and the expense drove me to find a cheaper place to live.

The actual job requires no skills and nearly no work besides opening the door, reading the Post, and being friendly around Christmas, and there are lots of qualified people who can replace them (not to mention 'virtual doormen'.

Hopefully they will come to a reasonable agreement, but I could see the coop and condo buildings (where apt owners pay the doormen) taking a harder line than the rental buildings.

Yipes! I had to read that headline twice, to be sure I wasn't reading "The Onion." You've got to be kidding, right?

Maybe the Tea Party will resolve this one?
How on earth do apartment dwellers in every other city in America manage to live without doormen?  Maybe it's NYC residents who have no conception of real life.

Let me get something clear - these doormen want more money, in these hard times, just for opening a door? Here's a solution - get rid of the doormen and save the $$. Let NY'ers open their own doors and tell these greedy doormen to take a hike!

Unions can be important in ensuring safe and decent working conditions and fair and approriate salaries and benefits for their members through collective bargaining and sometimes through strikes. Unions also can help establish minimal standards for worker competencies through training and testing, as well as quality standards, worker ethics, etc.

Yet unions also can act as bullying, intimidating and strong arming/threatening organizations when they use strikes and picket lines to block vital goods and services, especially to dependent people, like the occupants of residential housing. Many of these people are elderly and disabled. Many of these people are barely managing to pay their rents or maintenance payments along with their other expenses, including health care, drugs, food, utilities. Many of these folks are the elderly, retirees, chronically unemployed, including former union members and other workers who have lost jobs in this and other recessions and industrial downsizings.

So I come back to the issue of fairness. I think it is fair for union workers to receive periodic cost of living increases in tune with inflation. On the other hand, demanding increases simply because the union seeks higher wages for workers over and above inflation is not fair, especially in these challenging conditions. It also is unfair for the union to fight to prevent improvements or corrections in shortfalls in worker productivity or competence. Both sides should negotiate in good faith with the fairness principle in mind. Both sides should be open to reasonable compromises.

Residential buildings from the perspective of the residents are not businesses--they are the life support, the shelter for these people. It is one thing for unions to press profit making businesses that have the power to increase prices to consumers or increase productivity by introducting better procedures or technologies/machines. But the only source of revenues to pay higher salaries and benefits to union workers are through increases in rents and maintenance payments from the residents. Something that many of these people simply cannot afford.

I've lived in my doorman building for over 40 years. The makeup of the tenants in this building has changed radically since I first moved in. Once it was those of us artists, actors, teachers, all struggling  who 'dared' live above 14th Street. There was a lovely, warm and familiar vibe with the guys who work here and tend to the upkeep of the building. Since it has gone co-op the tenants arrived with bigger incomes and even bigger attitudes, oh, and a co-op board rules— ugh! In many cases the doormen are treated like servants. They are all intelligent, hard working and most have families to support. Some go to school at night. They not only deal with the demands of entitled tenants, but the children, the dogs, the packages, the trash, the complaints, the inability of tenants to unload their cars after returning from country escapes loaded with luggage. My own economic demise after I lost my job in publishing notwithstanding, I am never treated with anything less than respect and affection from these guys. I hope they get everything they need.

I find it hard to have sympathy for the tenants in these buildings. They choose to live in these buildings/co-op's knowing that they want the status, amenities, and benifits of such a property that offers such comforts and conveniences. Yes in this ecomony finances are tight for many people, but they choose to live there knowing they could afford it with the income they have and have no room to complain unless they have taken drastic salary/pay cuts. As for Co-Op'ers I have no sympathy, its a business (yes you have to pay maintanence on the building as would every owner of a home) and they can afford it. Otherwise background checks on income or finances wouldn't be one of the many prerequisite to be considered for tenantship. These workers protect you and your home, keep everything clean (so you don't have to shovel 4 feet of snow), have seen you at your best and worst, don't be surprised but know more about you than you think, helped you even if it isn't part of their job, and yet they want to take away benefits, cut pay, remove pensions, and seniority. I truely wonder if this was occuring at the jobs of these tenants where their companies decided to cut their pay,take away their benefits, their seniority, and remove their pensions all together if they would be accepting of such an idea?

The leftwing mentally ill arrogance is just appalling...is that an apt description of the typical NYT reader?

Do you think that just b/c a person has a doorman, they are rich? Given how the 304,000 public union employees of NYC have spent decades raping the city, the primary reason it is so expensive to live here, and why the TRUE unemployment rate is some 15-20%, or more - I am not of mind right now on a LIMTED, middle class budget to spend EVEN MORE on unionized workers with pensions I don't get, guaranteed job security, health benefits far better than mine in the private sector, etc.

Given the terrible economy, lack of skills needed for the job, and plethora of unemployed, I would replace every doorman who strikes- all of them.

Enough is enough...
Why don't New Yorkers open their own stupid doors?

I'm a doorman in NY. I've been a doorman for 10 yrs so far. Let me explain a
few things. If the average salary for a doorman, porter, concierge, is
40,500 dollars (before taxes), and the pay out per worker for benefits
is $12,300 (roughly). How does that add up to $70,000? Well, I guess that's
why I'm a doorman, "my math ain't so good". Now it's not only about
money. We have 10 sick days, RAB wants to cut those in half. On
top of that, we have to pay $100 a month towards our benefits. On
top of that, they wanna keep maximum pay unattainable for 5 yrs for
new hires. And they wouldn't get a pension, or full benefits. Now
taking that into consideration, they would like to remove seniority
(considering layoffs and new hires), so that means they can layoff
whom ever they choose when times are "tough". And afterwards hire
someone off the street to work there, for less pay for 5 yrs. What
says they can't fire that kid just before he hits full pay maturity?
Bottom line is we want a fair deal. We aren't asking for anyones
blood, We just want to be able to support our families (financially
and health insurance wise) and be able to continue living in this
expensive city. Average 1 bedroom apartment rates in the outer
boroughs are roughly 1000 a month and up. That's 2 paychecks at least.
Owners are saying times are tough. Well, we are saying, we get the
hint.
Bwa-hahahaha!

#10, Nancy raises an important point, "Maybe this strike will shed light on the very good pay a doorman makes (40,500, not including tips and benefits). Many go to school for 4 years (college degree)and cannot even get a job offer for 35,000. A social worker studies for 6 years and only earns 35,000 at first job. A teacher in New York has to study for 6 years and beginning salary is 41,000. But a doorman needs No Education and still earns 40,500 plus tips and benefits."

It is the issue regarding the additional income that building workers earn from tips. Tip-based income may be down due to the harsh economic climate and the fact that many residents are stretched to the limit right now. But the good news for the union members is that as the economy recovers, these tips should begin to recover as well.

Of course, tips may vary widely from neighborhood/building and worker roles, but I suspect that in some cases this income may be substantial. There is also the issue of how much of this supplemental income is subject to taxes, as a dollar of untaxed income is worth far more than one dollar of taxable income, especially at the marginal rates when it is added on to the base salaries, and also, in dual income households, to the combined joint returns.

I think the attacks on the residents of doorman buildings based on the delusion that people who live in doorman buildings are affluent is mean spirited and frankly dumb. Many people who live in doorman buildings live there because the only housing available in the area for them happened to be in doorman buildings. Many people who live in doorman buildings do so because they physically need to live in buildings with elevators because they are elderly or disabled. Others chose to rent or buy in doorman buildings while they were in their working years and earned much more money, but now are retired and barely get along on Social Security or pensions, or whatever nest egg they were able to accumulate over time. Many women feel the need to live in doorman buildings for reasons of safety and security. Those who criticize the residents of doorman buildings for seeking to keep their rents and maintenance expenses under control on the grounds that these people are affluent are totally out of line. The only issue is what is fair and appropriate on the salary, benefit and work rule area.
